title: Children of Men (9/10) Movie CLIP - Miracle Cease Fire (2006) HD

comments.text:
I truly think this is the single most awe-inspiring scene in modern cinema, 
and it has been seen by too few people. This movie is fantastic in almost 
every aspect: its choice of actors and performances, use of music, strong 
political messages, symbolism, ugly portrayal of war, and this scene here.﻿

comments.author: Daniel Mejia

comments.text:
People THIS is the spirit we should have! Amazing how a scene, just a scene 
in a movie (dont get me wrong, an amazing, soul-touching and truth-telling 
movie) makes us all hope, reunite, hope together and love eachother! Even 
in the comment section of youtube!! As if we recognise something much 
nobler and pure and sincere in each other and ourselves...

Well this is what we should live for! This is what we should emanate in 
everyday life! To everyone! Starting from our families (as fucked up as 
they are!) Forgive our dads or mums or brothers or sisters!

Let's co-create this hope! Let us hope together!
Let us be more divinly human and humanly divine! 
Because this is the kingdom of God...

A virtual hug to you all... ﻿

comments.author: Mohammed Azam Hussain

comments.text:
I shed a few tears because of this scene. Particularly just before it when 
he told the rebel "...It's a girl." I couldn't hold it in any longer. Then 
the gunshots rang. The opera'esque music in the background, the baby 
wailing over all the music, continuing to silence, the soldier that got 
down on one knee...
Amazing. Simply amazing.﻿

won more oscars. ﻿

comments.text:
A great scene.  But when I saw this movie, I kept thinking that if she's 
the only woman who can give birth, the human race is still going to die 
out.﻿
comments.author: sonoki82

comments.text:
+Skogze Well, women can produce about 500 developed eggs over their fertile 
lifetimes, but these are drawn from a huge number of undeveloped egg cells 
which die off. Depending on how old she is, this woman might have tens of 
thousands of undeveloped eggs in her body.  I suppose you could imagine a 
future technology which would allow all those undeveloped eggs to be 
extracted, matured in a lab and then fertilized.  You could imagine the 
controversy over doing this to the only woman in the world who is fertile. 
If they had that tech, and if they took the risk in using it, they would 
still need at least some of the wombs of other women on Earth to be 
functioning normally, to accept the fertilized eggs and nourish them. If 
the wombs of other women aren't working, then you'd have to imagine yet 
another sci-fi technology like an artificial womb to carry the fetuses to 
term. As far as I remember, there was nothing in the book or the movie 
about tech like this existing.
comments.author: sonoki82

comments.text:
couldn't they extract her eggs and make shit loads of female tube babies or 
something? (not an expert on this)
comments.author: Skogze

comments.text:
+sonoki82 That was the point of bringing her to the human project. So she 
can not only be safe and they can hopefully find a solution for human 
infertility.
comments.author: sid300e

comments.text:
+Oliver Gall Right, but do the math.  Even if she churns out babies until 
she hits menopause, and even if they are all born alive and are not 
infertile, and even if they are all girls, that's maybe 2 dozen girls.  If 
you fast forward 1 century from the ending of the movie, humankind will be 
reduced the population of a small village.  Maybe I shouldn't have said 
"died out" but it would still be catastrophic.

Interestingly, in the book, it is male infertility that is the problem, and 
all frozen sperm in sperm banks has also been corrupted. The savior of 
humanity is not a woman, but one of the male terrorists, whose nut sack 
contains working sperm.  So in the book's scenario, it will be a lot easier 
to create a whole lotta babies right away, but after that humanity will 
have a huge inbreeding problem.
comments.author: sonoki82

it out completely. Only a few vials of polio exist in research labs.

comments.author: Dan Wendelstein (Atvishees)

comments.text:
This is one of my favorite scenes, period. Because it shows the mystery and 
importance in birth. That's why I really hate abortion. Because we don't 
know or understand everything about being born and dying. And some people 
argue you're not a human until you're born. But then you're just playing 
God. Where was it written in the universe that an unborn human isn't human? 
How can we say that with such certainty? And perhaps it really isn't a 
person. But the point is, we don't know. We know so little. And I truly 
think abortions are just tampering with life. Of course I don't think this 
scene is a statement on abortions. But I do appreciate how it defines the 
importance of birth, life, and the mystery. ﻿
comments.author: Hive Atlas

comments.text:
None of those statements are factually true. By that logic, where was it 
written in the universe that and unborn human is a person? Nothing was 
written anywhere, the universe doesn't much care.

http://dresdencodak.com/2009/09/22/caveman-science-fiction/

Yep, I can already see joining this conversation is the dumbest thing I'm 
doing today.
comments.author: btaens

comments.text:

comments.text:
+Hive Atlas
Actually before the brain develops in the womb the baby is not alive 
per-say but is still growing so that is why abortion is legal in the first 
24-32 weeks then you have to have a doctor confirm it so it can be done. 
After it that is illegal or the doctor sais you can't have an abortion. 
Also what right do you have to make a decision for someone else. It is the 
woman and man's decision if they're together or woman and woman to do it 
and what if the woman is sick like the baby is causing problems do you want 
them to suffer? So you should think long and hard about topics like this 
before blurting things out like that.
comments.author: Seth Prescott

comments.text:
+bulaluigi I never said anything about valuing the fetus more than the 
mother. My point is that a fetus is still a human life, and we shouldn't be 
tampering with life. 

In response to you saying, "Do some research", I have done research on 
abortions. 

I think I'm done talking to you too. Its possible to disagree with someone 
without being mean and hurtful. But you're angry and dismissive. It would 
have been nice to have a healthy conversation and try to understand each 
other's views better.   

Whoever you are, I wish you the best. Peace.
comments.author: Hive Atlas

comments.text:
+Hive Atlas I don't care to have any kind of civil discourse with you 
because you value an undeveloped fetus more than the welfare of the mother 
and the child after he/she is born.  

And abortions are not 'new.' Do some research.
comments.author: bulaluigi

comments.text:
+bulaluigi  I think it depends what you mean by civilization. When did 
humans become "civilized"? On top of that, people groups and cultures are 
very diverse. But even when it comes to "civilization" and diverse 
cultures, abortions are very new to humanity. Even the type of birth 
control we have today is very new to humanity.

If something is "normal", that doesn't make it right. There are a lot of 
normal things that are bad, like sweatshops or war. Though at the end of 
the day we'll probably disagree on the topic of abortion, I'll still make 
the point that it's important to for normality to not be our moral 
standard. 

I'm not trying to upset you, yell at you, or belittle you. I'm just trying 
to have a conversation about the topic and reply to the comment you posted.
comments.author: Hive Atlas

comments.text:

comments.author: Pretzel Stick

comments.text:
+hank0rz The difference between your shit is those cells will never amount 
to anything, the other cells will result in life.

It's not a question of that person being informed, it's a question of what 
you value. An abortion of any kind in Children of Men would be illegal for 
obvious reasons, those same cells you have no regard for, would mean the 
survival of mankind to doctors in this movie.

And no, we don't know 'exactly' everything. We know the process, we don't
